Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Cell and Molecular Visualization at Brandeis University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU award to Brandeis University, located in Waltham, MA will support the training of 10 undergraduate students for 10 weeks in the summers of 2014-2016. The research theme of modern cell and molecular visualization techniques reflects the common interest among 50 faculty in the Life Sciences at Brandeis. These mentors will introduce undergraduate students to a broad range of topics concerning biological structure and function. Training will take place in a supportive and interactive environment with state-of-the-art facilities, and the participating faculty have a strong record of mentorship of undergraduates for research. In addition, students will participate in weekly lunch seminars, which will include faculty research presentations, professional development activities, and career panels. Students will have an opportunity to interact with scientists with diverse interests and at different stages in their careers. In addition, there will be group discussions of ethical issues and the mentorship relationship in science. Students will develop a written synopsis of their summer work, with feedback and editing and will participate in a capstone symposium including poster presentations.

Students will be recruited from a nation-wide pool through the web, as well as personal outreach at undergraduate research conferences and visits to institutions with limited opportunities for research. Participants will be selected based on academic record, recommendations and potential for research in biology. The value of the experience for students and mentors will be measured by various assessment instruments, including the BIO REU common assessment tool.

The impact of the experience will be monitored by tracking students for continued interest in science, further educational choices and career paths. More information can be obtained by visiting http://www.bio.brandeis.edu/undergrad/summerresearch or by contacting Director, Dr. Susan Lovett at lovett@brandeis.edu or the Co-Director, Dr. Joan Press at press@brandeis.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded 30 undergraduate students from across the nation for a 10-week summer research experience at Brandeis University from 2014-2016. Over half of these students came from undergraduate institutions with limited resources for research and half came from groups under-represented in science. They joined over 20 different active research laboratories for hands-on training. The theme of the program was "Cellular and Molecular Visualization": in essense, looking at biological molecules using a variety of techniques to learn about their structure and function in biology. The objective of the program was to provide an authentic research experience that would provide skills and knowledge to prepare undergraduate students for PhD programs and careers in biological research. 

Students participated in weekly seminars, which included research presentations, ethics discussions and professional development activities such as panel discussion with students and postdoctoral fellows for careers in medicine, biotechnology and research. Students developed a written synopsis of their summer work, receiving feedback and editing from the coordinators, and participated in a capstone symposium where they presented their summer project on a poster. Students had an opportunity to interact with many active researchers at various stages in their careers, who shared their personal experiences in navigating a career in science.  

Surveys of participants indicated a strong gains in understanding how research is done and their confidence in their ability to contribute to science. In addition, most participants indicated that they were more likely to apply to PhD programs in science as a result of their experience. 

Intellectual Merit of the project: Training took place in a supportive and interactive environment with state-of-the-art facilities.The program supported research activities of 20 different laboratories at Brandeis University concerned with aspects of cell and molecular biology and neuroscience. Students from the program were authors on 5 research publications.

Broader impacts of the project: The 3-year program promoted broadened participation in research by providing a meaningful research experience to students from groups under-represented in science or those with limited opportunities to engage in research at their home institutions. All participants came away with a deeper knowledge of the research process. Training programs like this promote diversity in science by providing opportunities to talented students, regardless of ethnicity and economic status.
